ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Have you ever had a period lasting one month or longer when most of the time you felt worried, tense, or anxious?
Notes: GAD = General Anxiety Disorder Section; 1 = Yes; 2 = No; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: People differ a lot in how much they worry about things. Did you ever have a time whe you worried a lot more than most people would in your situation
What is the longest period of time that this kind of worrying have ever continued

Please think of the period in your life when you have felt worried, tense, anxious, or more worried than most people would in your situation. This could be in the past, or it oculd be continuing now. During that paeriod, was your worry stronger than in other people?
Did you worry most days?
Did you usually worry about one particular thing, such as your job security or the failing health of a loved one, or more tha on ething?
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No; 3= One Thing; 4= More Than One Thing; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Did you find it difficult to stop worrying?
Did you ever have different worries on your mind at the same time?
How often was your worry so strong that you couldn't put it out of your mind no matter how hard you tried?
Notes: 1 = Often; 2 = Sometimes; 3 = Rarely; 4 = Never; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: How often did you find it diffiult to control your worry?
Notes: 1 = Often; 2 = Sometimes; 3 = Rarely; 4 = Never; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: When you were worried or anxious, were you also restless?
Restlessness or feeling keyed-up or on edge.
Easily tired
Having difficulty keeping your mind on what you were doing?
More irritable than usual?
Having tense, sore, or aching muscles?
Often having trouble falling or staying asleep?
Did you ever tell a professional about these problems (medical doctor, psychologist, social worker, counselor, nurse, clergy, or other helping professional)?
Did you take medication or use drugs or alcohol more than once for the worry or the problems it was causing?
How much did the worry or anxiety interfere with your life or activities?

SPS = Specific Phobia Section; The next questions are about things that make some people so afraid that they avoid them, even when there is no real danger. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear or avoid any of the following things; Heights, storms, thunder, lightning, or being in still water, like a swimming pool or lakes?
Being in a closed space like a cave, tunnel, elevator, or airplane?
Snakes, birds, rats, bugs, or other animals?
Seeing blood, getting a shot, or injection, seeing a dentist, or going to a hospital
Please think of the situations you fear such as: How often do you get upset when you are in that situation?
Notes: 5 = Everytime; 2 = Most of the time; 3 = Some of the time [go to social phobia section]; 4 = Only one or two times ever [go to Social Phobia Section];5 = Never [go to social phobia section]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not asked

ElementDescription: How long have you had any of these fears?
Notes: 3 = More than 5 years; 2 = Between 1 and 5 years; 1 = Less than 1 years (Record # of months); -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: How much have any of these fears ever interfered with your life or activities?
Notes: 4 = Not at all; 3 = A little; 2 = Some; 1 = A lot; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Have you ever been very upset with yourself for having any of these fears?
Is your fear unreasonable - that is, much stronger than it should be?
Is your fear much strong than in other people?

Here's another list of situations that can cause unreasonably strong fears. They involve doing things in front of other people or neing the center of attention. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear or avoid any of the following situations: Giving a speech or speaking in public?
Notes: SPSS = Social Phobia Section; 1= Yes; 2= No

ElementDescription: Eating or drinking where someone could watch you?
Talking to people because you might have nothing to say or might sound foolish?
Writing while someone watches?
Taking part of speaking in a meeting or class?
Going to a party or other social outing?
Please think only of the situations that cause you unreasonably strong fears such as: How often do you get very upset when you are in this situation?
Notes: 5 = Never [go to agoraphobia section]; 4 = Only one or two times ever [go to agoraphobia section]; 3 = Some of the time [go to agoraphobia section]; 2 = Most of the time; 1 = Every time; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not asked

ElementDescription: How long have you had any of these fears?
Notes: 3 = More than 5 years; 2 = Between 1 and 5 years; 1 = Less than 1 years (Record # of months); -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: How much have any of these fears ever interfered with your life or activities?
Notes: 4 = Not at all; 3 = A little; 2 = Some; 1 = A lot; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Have you ever been very upset with yourself for having any of these fears?
Is your fear unreasonable - that is, much stronger than it should be?
Is your fear much stronger than in other people?
Here's a final list of situations that can cause unreasonably strong fears. Do you have an unreasonably strong fear for or avoid any of the following: Being in a crowd or standing in line?
Being away from home alone?
Traveling alone?
Traveling in a bus, train, or car?
Being in a public place like a department store?
Please think only of situation(s) that cause you to have unreasonably strong fears, such as: How often do you get very upset in the sitatuons?
Notes: 5 = Everytime; 2 = Most of the time; 3 = Some of the time [go to panic attack section]; 4 = Only one or two times ever [go to panic attack Section];5 = Never [go to panic attack section]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not asked

ElementDescription: How long have you had any of these fears?
Notes: 3 = More than 5 years; 2 = Between 1 and 5 years; 1 = Less than 1 years (Record # of months); -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Were you ever afraid that you might faint, lose control, or embarrass yourself in other ways?
Do you worry that you might be trapped without any way to escapre?
Do you worry that help might not be available if you needed it?
How much did any o these fears ever interfere with your life or activities
Notes: 4 = Not at all; 3 = A little; 2 = Some; 1 = A lot; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Did you ever have a spell or an attack when all of a sudden you felt frightened, anxious, or very unseasy?
Notes: PAS = Panic Attack Section; 1 = Yes; 2 = No; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Did any of these attacks occur when you were in a life-threating situation? 9if skip, go to 35b]
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No [go to 36]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Did any of these attacks occur when you were not in a life-threatening situation?
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No [Part I is complete]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: About how many attacks have you had in your life?
Please enter the number of attacks you have had in your life in the box below:
Notes: Any # of attacks; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: How long ago did you have your most recent attack?
Notes: Score in months; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Did some of your attacks happen in a situation when you were not in danger or not the center of attention
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No [go to 36]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: We already asked about specific situatuons that cause unreasonably strong fears (heights, elevators, snakes, etc.). - When you have sudden anxiety attacks, do they usually occur in specific situations that cause you unreasonably strong fear?
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No [go to 40]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: Did you ever have an attack when you were not in a situation that usually causes you to have unreasonably strong fears?
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No [Part I is complete]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not Asked

ElementDescription: When you have attacks: Does your heart pound or race?
Do you have tightness, pain, or discomfort in your chest or stomach?
Do you sweat?
Do you tremble or shake?
Chills or hot flashes.
Do you, or things around you, seem unreal?
How much did the worry or anxiety interfere with your life or activities?
Notes: 1= A lot; 2= Some; 3= A little; 4= Not at all; -1= Refused; -2= Not Asked

ElementDescription: Please think of the situations you fear such as: How often do you get upset when you are in that situation?
Notes: 1 = Everytime; 2 = Most of the time; 3 = Some of the time [go to social phobia section]; 4 = Only one or two times ever [go to Social Phobia Section];5 = Never [go to social phobia section]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not asked

ElementDescription: Please think only of situation(s) that cause you to have unreasonably strong fears, such as: How often do you get very upset in the sitatuons?
Notes: 1 = Everytime; 2 = Most of the time; 3 = Some of the time [go to social phobia section]; 4 = Only one or two times ever [go to Social Phobia Section];5 = Never [go to social phobia section]; -1 = Refused; -2 = Not asked
